Posts.Content: Jul 21, 2012 02:22PM ibahammer wrote: Acon, Hi, its good that you have continued to pursue this issue.  Why haven't any of the doctors sent you to get a mammogram or a mammogram with a diagnostic ultrasound?  I don't have implants yet so maybe there is a different course of action for people with implants but I would be persistant until they can give you a definative answer as to why you have pain and an inverted nipple.  If these doctors don't take your concerns seriously then switch to a different doctor because you are the patient and your best advocate!  I wish you all of the best!
Posts.Title: Not Diagnosed but Worried acon acon

Posts.Content: Jul 22, 2012 12:29PM ibahammer wrote: My insurance made it difficult to get a MRI and the imagining center wouldn't allow me to make an appointment until my insurance approved the MRI. My insurance company required results from the mammogram, diagnostic ultrasound and core biopsy before they would okay the MRI.  Hopefully you won't have to go through all of that before you can get a MRI. The MRI is far more accurate than a mammogram or a diagnostic ultrasound but its also more expensive so my insurance company wasn't really cooperative in the beginning.  Since you have implants maybe they will allow you to bypass some of the steps that were required of me.  Again, wishing you the best!
Posts.Title: Not Diagnosed but Worried acon acon

Posts.Content: Feb 4, 2013 01:31PM ibahammer wrote: Purple32,  Hi, I have had a pair of sleeves and gauntlets.  Both were Juzo.  In the beginning I was instructed to hand wash them in cold water with baby detergent and to air dry them.  This was great when I only needed them to fly.  When I needed to use them daily at the gym it was kind of a hassle, but do-able.  As the sleeves get older they start to give a little and to combat that my fitter instructed me to wash them in the washing machine with regular detergent in warm water and to toss them in the dryer on a low setting.  The pair I had is just about done because it has too much give now at the wrist where the sleeve meets the gauntlet.  I can now treat them like regular clothes and dry them on regular heat.  They aren't perfect but they are better than nothing until I get my new one piece sleeve and gauntlet.  I can't remember the brand but if I end up liking them I will post it.  My insurance company will not cover any ready made compression garments.  They have to be custom made to be cover.  They also have to be 20-30 mm HG or greater.  I have yet to find out percentage they will cover on custom compression garment because I need to meet my deductible again and to have specific codes before I can approach them.  I need compression garments for the axililary and chest as well. Some of the compression garments for truncal lymphedema are seriously expensive.  I also haven't found one that fits me well so in the meantime I have been using under armor.  Again, not a perfect solution but better than nothing when I am experiencing truncal lymphedema.  Good luck with your fact finding; I think the information will be relevent to a lot of us!
Posts.Title: ALL THINGS Gloves and sleeves purple32 tsoebbin
